Dear Harry:
Dean Moore of our School of Music has called to the atten¬
tion of Lyle Nelson, Director of University Relations, and the
Chairman of the Executive Committee on Broadcasting certain
phrases in the Smather Bill which is before Congress.
The Dean’s note reads in part as follows:
”In clearing my desk at home, I came across
’’Books from Ann Arbor, The University Press, Spring,
1958.” On one of the pages I find a listing of a
publication of music, namely, Ross Lee Finney,
'Sixth String Quartet in E,' and 'Quintet for Piano
and Strings.'
This started a train of thought in my mind
relative to the Smather Bill. The University Press
has published other items of music, namely, two very
large works by Louise Cuyler, and we anticipate the
press continuing such publication when available
scholarly transcriptions or new compositions appear
to be appropriate.
The point at issue is that the Smather Bill,
if enacted, would prohibit the University of Michigan
Press from such publications or the University would
have to give up its Radio Station, and I quote Section
1 of the Bill: 'No construction permit or license
for broadcasting stations shall be granted to or held
by any person or corporation engaged in or which owns
any interest in, a corporation engaged in the business
of publishing music or of manufacturing or selling re¬
cordings of musical compositions.' Another paragraph
of the Bill proposes: 'If any licensee is in violation
of paragraph 1 (quoted above), on the date of enact¬
